newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela labor strife grows, teachers to strike.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela labor strife grows, teachers to strike.

text.p: Venezuelan university teachers said on Tuesday they would begin an indefinite strike on Wednesday, adding to growing labour strife that threatens to sink the government's inflation-fighting economic programme.
More than 40,000 teachers at 17 universities will walk-out on some half a million students over an average 125 percent promised pay claim the government calls exaggerated.
"The government has not complied with its legally mandated pay increase," University Professor Union President Jose Rafael Casal said.

The teachers' demands fan already heated wage talks between striking Venezuelan doctors and the government over a 300 percent pay increase that many view as a test of the government's will to stonewall union calls for higher wages.
"The arrangement that is finally settled with the doctors will set a precedent for wider public pay settlements," said Labour Minister Juan Nepomuceno Garrido in a television interview on Tuesday.

Doctors have so far rejected an across the board 25 percent public sector pay increase. A seven truce day truce in the strike, which authorities charge left 15 dead in unattended emergency wards, expires on Wednesday night. The strike began on Dec. 27.
Interior Minister Guillermo Andueza said "the (labor) situation is not generalized ... there is social peace."
But the strikes, which includes judges, illustrate the drama of a recession-battered middle class employed by, and increasingly dependent on, notoriously poor public services.
"The (doctor's) strike is the beginning of the struggle of the middle class," the more normally restrained El Nacional daily said in a recent editorial.

While improving macroeconomic indicators have dazzled Wall Street since Venezuela implemented a series of International Monetary Fund supported reforms last April, ministers acknowledge that over 100 percent inflation in 1996 has laid waste to real wages.
However, they also urge public sector workers to show wage restraint and tighten belts further to help bring inflation down to 25 percent this year.
"If we don't keep a firm hand, we'll loose the ground gained and everyone must understand this," President Rafael Caldera said in his traditional end-of-year message.
"The hydra-headed monster of inflation, of which we've cut off a head, could come back," he added.
